Always ask to see ID badges. All FEMA representatives carry an identification badge with a photograph. A FEMA shirt or jacket is not proof of identity.

If you doubt a FEMA representative is legitimate, hang up and call the FEMA Helpline at 800-621-3362 or the National Center for Fraud Hotline at 866-720-5721 to report the incident. Complaints also may be made by contacting local law enforcement agencies.

FEMA representatives will ask for social security and bank account numbers when you apply and may ask for it again after you apply. Be cautious when giving this information to others who ask for it. Scammers may pose as government officials, aid workers, or insurance companies

Do not disclose information to any unsolicited telephone calls and e-mails from individuals claiming to be FEMA or federal employees.
FEMA will not contact you unless you have called FEMA first or applied for assistance.

Federal and local disaster workers do not solicit or accept money. Don‚Äôt trust anyone who offers financial help and then asks for money or personal information. The Department of Homeland Security, FEMA, or any other U.S. agency never charge for assistance. (Thread).
